dataIdInfo.envirDesc: Microsoft Windows Vista Version 6.0 (Build 6002) Service Pack 2; Esri ArcGIS 10.1.1.3143

idCitation.resTitle: Rent Affordability Gap by Neighborhood, San Francisco, CA

dataIdInfo.idPurp: The data illustrate the number of minimum wage jobs that would be required to afford a two-bedroom rental unit at fair market rent value in San Francisco, as well as the gap between the median neighborhood household income and the estimated household income needed to afford a two bedroom unit at the Fair Market Rate rental price as assessed from Craigslist listings posted during July-December 2012.
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
The U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) defines Fair Market Rent (FMR) as the dollar amount below which 40% of the standard-quality rental housing units are rented, including all utilities except telephone/cable/internet service. HUD uses rental price information from the American Community Survey to establish local FMR's that are used to determine how much rent government housing assistance programs should cover. However, it is often noted that current rental costs listed through common online rental listings websites are higher than the FMR established by HUD. In order to calculate FMR based on rental listings from the online posting board Craigslist.org (a popular, mainstream avenue for finding rental housing in the Bay Area), a sample of 92,411 Craigslist rental listings from the second half of 2012 was geocoded and aggregated by neighborhood. From this sample, listing prices for two-bedroom apartments were identified for 11,878 unique locations within San Francisco. Craiglist FMR was calculated for each neighborhood according to the 40th percentile of listing prices. The median listing price for each neighborhood was also calculated.

The number of full-time minimum-wage jobs necessary to afford a two-bedroom apartment in each neighborhood was calculated based on the methodology published by the National Low Income Housing Coalition (NLIHC). In keeping with NLIHCâ€™s methodology, our calculations assumed that rent (at the fair market rate) is 30% of the monthly household budget, and that a full-time minimum wage worker works 40 hours per week, 52 weeks per year.

The neighborhood affordability gap is calculated by subtracting the neighborhood median income, calculated from American Community Survey (ACS) data, from the income required to afford a two-bedroom apartment at the Craigslist fair market rent (FMR) for the last 6 months of 2012, assuming rent is 30% of the household budget.

Field Definitions

Nhood: San Francisco planning neighborhood;

Pop2010: 2010 population estimate;

MedianRent: median housing unit rental based on a sample of Craigslist listings from 2012;

sample_siz: Number of properties listed within each neighborhood from Craigslist data;

FMR: Fair Market Rent, the dollar amount below which 40% of the Craigslist 2-bedroom properties were listed;

Income_d: Estimated income needed to afford the median priced 2-bedroom rental unit based on the assumption that rent is 30% of the monthly household budget;

MinW_2012: Minimum wage in San Francsico;

FT_jobs: Number of full time minimum-wage jobs needed to afford Craigslist fair market rent for a 2-bedroom unit;

MedInc_d: Median Household Income based on the American Community Survey;

MedInc_moe: Median Household Income margin of error;

Income_gap: The difference between median income of neighborhood and estimated median income needed to afford a two-bedroom apartment at current Craigslist fair market rent.

Sources

US Census Bureau, 2005-2009 American Community Survey

Craigslist.org listings provided by Padmapper.com for July-December 2012

Minimum Wage in San Francisco: Minimum Wage Ordinance. City & County of San Francisco Office of Labor Standards Enforcement. Accessed online: http://sfgsa.org/index.aspx?page=411.

National Low Income Housing Coalition. Out of Reach 2012. March 2012. http://nlihc.org/oor/2012
dataIdInfo.idCredit: City/County of San Francisco Department of Public Health, Environmental Health, Program on Health Equity and Sustainability, http://www.sfphes.org

Consts.useLimit:
SFDPH Disclaimer: This data is being provided as public information as defined under San Francisco and California public records laws. The San Francisco Department of Public Health (SFDPH, or the Department) cannot limit or restrict the use of this data or its interpretation by other parties in any way. Where the data is communicated, distributed, reproduced, mapped, or used in any other way, the user should acknowledge SFDPH as the source of the data, provide a reference to the original data source where also applicable, and note any caveats specified in the associated methodological documentation provided by the Department. However, users should not attribute their analysis or interpretation of this data to SFDPH. While the data has been collected and/or produced for the use of SFDPH, the Department cannot guarantee its accuracy or completeness. As all data is associated with methodological assumptions and limitations, the Department recommends that users review methodological documentation associated with the data prior to its analysis, interpretation, or communication.

American Community Survey (ACS) is a sample survey that does not survey every household. The values presented are statistical estimates; the true value is likely to be within a range represented by margins of error. The 90% margins of error provided with this dataset were calculated by statisticians at the US Census Bureau. The margins of error (MOE) can be subtracted from and added to each value to obtain the range of values that could represent the true value.

Generally margins of error represent a narrower range where sample sizes are larger. Thus where possible we have provided data collected continuously over five years instead of one year. However the multi-year sampling time frame means that the data do not reflect conditions at any single point in time.

In some cases, the data for specific census tracts lack the statistical reliability to be presented (we use a coefficient of variation/relative standard error of >0.3). This usually results from the population of interest being too small, either because few people live in that geographic area or because few people fall into the category being analyzed (e.g. a very small number of people are unemployed, therefore estimates for unemployment are unreliable).

More information and background on ACS data can be found in the ACS compass handbooks: http://www.census.gov/acs/www/guidance_for_data_users/handbooks/.

Listings on Craigslist may be inherently biased toward certain demographics and may not be representative of all sectors of the rental market in San Francisco. Where there were multiple listings for the same location at the same price, these were assumed to be re-listings for the same unit, and thus were eliminated from the sample. However it is possible that some of these may represent multiple units at the same location.

Treasure Island is excluded because there were very few listings during the sample period (n = 3).
